activity_citation.rationale: The authority comes from the established, universal practice of these narrative-driven industries. The sequence of mapping an emotional arc and then building the plot around it is a core principle of character-driven storytelling.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Map Emotional Arc
Outline the Journey
Structure

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: This is a plausible synthesis of known network functions. Mapping an emotional arc involves simulating another's feelings (`DMN`, `Limbic`). Outlining and structuring are core executive functions (`ECN`).
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: The sequence represents a robust model of narrative planning, grounded in the known functions of the brain's emotional, simulative, and executive networks.

content.title: The User Journey Path
content.summary: Empathize -> Map Journeys (Happy & Unhappy) -> Prioritize
content.rationale: The standard for UX design, improved to combat 'happy path' bias by mandating the design of error and recovery experiences.
activity_sequence: Define a user persona and their goal.
Create a step-by-step map of the ideal 'happy path' experience.
Immediately after, map a critical 'unhappy path' (e.g., an error, a dead end) and the user's emotional journey through that failure and recovery.
Prioritize the key interactions from both maps to create a resilient design plan.

activity_citation.citation_text: This pathway codifies the core methodology of User Experience (UX) and Service Design.
activity_citation.rationale: The authority comes from the established, widespread professional practice in the UX industry. The "Unhappy Path" addition is a best practice for designing resilient and user-friendly systems.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Empathize
Map Journeys (Happy & Unhappy)
Prioritize

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: Saxe, R., & Kanwisher, N. (2003). People thinking about thinking people: The role of the temporo-parietal junction in 'theory of mind'. NeuroImage, 19(4), 1835-1842.
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: The sequence begins with empathy (`SCN`). The mapping of journeys involves both simulating the user's experience (`DMN`) and structuring it logically (`ECN`). The final prioritization is a value-based judgment (`vmPFC`). This is a robust model of user-centered design cognition.

content.title: The World-Building Path
content.summary: Define Conflict -> Establish World -> Create Story Hooks
content.rationale: For large-scale creative projects, improved to ensure the world is built in service of dramatic conflict, not just encyclopedic detail.
activity_sequence: First, define the central, unresolved conflict that is the engine of your world.
Establish the foundational physics, history, and cultural rules of the world in service of illuminating that core conflict.
Conclude by generating a portfolio of 3-5 compelling 'story hooks' that are direct products of the core conflict.

activity_citation.citation_text: This pathway describes the process used by creators like J.R.R. Tolkien or in large-scale game design (e.g., for franchises like The Elder Scrolls).
activity_citation.rationale: The authority comes from the established practice of successful world-builders. The principle of starting with a core conflict to ensure the world is dramatically interesting is a key lesson from these exemplars.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Define Conflict
Establish World
Create Story Hooks

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: This is a plausible synthesis of known network functions. Defining a conflict is a structured, analytical task (`ECN`). Establishing a world is a highly imaginative, associative task (`DMN`). Creating story hooks involves both generating ideas (`DMN`) and structuring them (`ECN`).
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: The sequence represents a robust model of large-scale creative planning, grounded in the known functions of the brain's executive and imaginative networks.

content.title: The Translation Prototype Path
content.summary: Create a low-fidelity, interactive prototype to translate an abstract concept into a tangible artifact for team alignment.
content.rationale: Bridges the critical gap between an abstract plan (Tool 5) and full execution (Tool 6). This path creates a 'translation artifact'—a tangible object for discussion—that makes the theoretical concept concrete, surfaces misunderstandings early, and ensures the entire team (content, design, engineering) shares the same mental model before expensive development begins.
activity_sequence: Take the most complex or abstract idea from the project plan.
Build the simplest possible interactive prototype that demonstrates its core mechanic or user flow.
Hold a review session where the content, design, and engineering teams interact with the prototype together.
Use the feedback from this session to create the final, detailed technical specifications for Tool 6.

activity_citation.citation_text: This pathway is derived from the principles of rapid prototyping and interaction design.
activity_citation.rationale: The authority comes from established best practices in the UX and software development industries. Using low-fidelity prototypes as "boundary objects" for cross-functional communication is a core tenet of modern, agile design processes.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Deconstruct the abstract concept into its core interactive components
Rapidly build a low-fidelity, interactive prototype (e.g., using paper, Figma, or a simple script)
Use the prototype as a 'boundary object' to facilitate a shared conversation and check for understanding

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: This is a plausible synthesis of known network functions. Deconstruction is an `ECN` task. Building the prototype involves both planning (`ECN`) and physical action (`Sensorimotor`). Facilitating a shared conversation is a core social-cognitive task (`SCN`, `Lang`).
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: The sequence represents a robust model of the cognitive steps involved in using a prototype to bridge the gap between abstract thought and shared understanding.

content.title: The Foundational Path
content.summary: Define Success -> Map the Terrain & Risks -> Create an Adaptive Plan
content.rationale: This is the universal, discipline-agnostic sequence for creating a robust plan. It ensures that any inquiry is grounded in a clear definition of success, an honest assessment of the known terrain and potential risks, and a structure that allows for adaptation.
activity_sequence: Co-create a clear 'Definition of Success' (N09) that is visible to the whole team.

Map the known terrain by creating a Concept Map (N10) of existing knowledge and, crucially, run a 'Pre-Mortem Exercise' (N11) to transform vague anxiety into a list of concrete, solvable problems (a CBT technique).
Create a formal plan that is not a rigid script, but an adaptive map that includes the destination, the known terrain, and the identified risks.

activity_citation.citation_text: This pathway synthesizes best practices from multiple fields. The 'Definition of Success' is from Agile (Sutherland, 2014), the 'Pre-Mortem' is from strategic management (Klein, 2007), and 'Concept Mapping' is from education and knowledge management.
activity_citation.rationale: The authority comes from the synthesis of multiple, well-validated techniques from different domains into a single, coherent workflow, which is the core purpose of this framework.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Define goals and principles, engaging the ECN and vmPFC to set a value-aligned destination.
Map the terrain by toggling between internal memory retrieval (DMN, Hippo) and external research (DAN).
Identify risks by simulating potential futures (DMN, Amygdala).
Formalize an adaptive plan using the ECN and Language Network.

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: This is a plausible synthesis of multiple known network functions. Goal-setting (`ECN`, `vmPFC`), memory retrieval (`DMN`), risk assessment (`Amygdala`), and planning (`ECN`) are all foundational cognitive processes.
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: The sequence represents a comprehensive model of strategic planning, integrating value-based goal setting, memory, prospection, and executive control in a logical and evidence-based manner.

content.title: The Political Buy-In Path
content.summary: Map Stakeholders -> Identify Key Influencers -> Co-create the Plan -> Secure Buy-in
content.rationale: A strategic pathway that uses stakeholder mapping not for discovery, but as a political and logistical tool. It ensures a project plan is not only technically sound but also has the necessary social and organizational support to succeed by proactively identifying dependencies and securing buy-in from key influencers.
activity_sequence: Conduct a Stakeholder Mapping (N03) exercise, focusing on influence and interest.
Identify the 1-3 key individuals whose support is critical for the plan's success.
Schedule individual or small-group sessions with these key stakeholders to get their feedback and incorporate their needs into the plan.
Present the final, co-created plan for formal approval.

activity_citation.citation_text: This pathway is derived from the principles of organizational change management and corporate strategy. A specific citation is less relevant than its validation through widespread, successful practice in large organizations.
activity_citation.rationale: The authority comes from established best practices in corporate strategy and change management. The sequence of mapping stakeholders, identifying influencers, and co-opting them into the planning process is a standard and effective method for ensuring a project's political viability.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Identify all stakeholders and map their influence and interest
Identify the key decision-makers and potential blockers
Engage key stakeholders in a co-creation process to build ownership
Formalize the plan and secure official buy-in

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: Saxe, R., & Kanwisher, N. (2003). People thinking about thinking people: The role of the temporo-parietal junction in 'theory of mind'. NeuroImage, 19(4), 1835-1842.
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: This entire sequence is a high-level application of the Social Cognition Network (`SCN`). Mapping influence, identifying key players, and engaging in co-creation are all complex social-cognitive tasks that rely on the brain's ability to model the minds, intentions, and power dynamics of other people.

content.title: The Ritual Path
content.summary: Anchor in Story -> Goal-set -> Define -> De-risk
content.rationale: A highly refined ritual that maximizes clarity and alignment, improved with a mandatory narrative step to anchor the analytical work in a shared human purpose.
activity_sequence: Begin the ceremony by having the Product Owner tell a compelling 2-minute story about the user whose problem the sprint aims to solve.
Based on this story, collaboratively define a clear Sprint Goal.
Co-create the Definition of Done and run a pre-mortem.

activity_citation.citation_text: Sutherland, J. (2014). Scrum: The Art of Doing Twice the Work in Half the Time. Currency.
activity_citation.rationale: This is the definitive guide to the Scrum framework by its co-creator. The pathway's sequence of defining a Sprint Goal and a Definition of Done is a direct application of the core ceremonies of Scrum. The "Anchor in Story" step is an addition from narrative leadership practices.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Set goal
Co-create DoD
Run pre-mortem
Finalize plan

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: This is a plausible synthesis of known network functions for collaborative planning. Goal-setting and planning are `ECN` tasks. Co-creating a shared definition of done is a social-cognitive task (`SCN`). The pre-mortem involves imagining a future failure, a core function of the `DMN`.
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: The sequence represents a robust model of the cognitive steps involved in a Scrum planning ceremony, integrating executive, social, and imaginative brain networks.

content.title: The Roadmapping Path
content.summary: Envision -> Prioritize (Now/Next/Later) -> Sprint
content.rationale: Connects short-term work to long-term strategy, improved by replacing the timeline-based roadmap with a structure that honestly communicates uncertainty.
activity_sequence: Define the 1-2 year product vision.
Structure the roadmap into three columns: 'Now' (current work, high certainty), 'Next' (upcoming 1-3 months, medium certainty), and 'Later' (future ideas, low certainty).
Pull the highest priority item from the 'Now' column to be the focus of the current sprint.

activity_citation.citation_text: This pathway codifies the "Now/Next/Later" roadmapping technique, a standard practice in modern, strategic product management.
activity_citation.rationale: The authority comes from established, widespread professional practice in the product management field. This method is valued for its honesty about uncertainty and its focus on outcomes over fixed timelines.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Envision long-term future
Break it into quarterly goals
Assess value vs. effort
Plan the first sprint

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: Buckner, R. L., & Carroll, D. C. (2007). Self-projection and the brain. Trends in Cognitive Sciences, 11(2), 49-57.
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: The sequence begins with long-term prospection (`DMN`). This vision is then broken down into a hierarchical plan by the `ECN`, a core executive function. The prioritization step involves value-based judgment (`vmPFC`). This is a robust model of strategic planning.

content.title: The Discovery Path
content.summary: Scan -> Identify -> Experiment -> Synthesize
content.rationale: Used in dynamic environments, improved with a mandatory synthesis step to prevent 'strategic drift' and ensure learnings are integrated.
activity_sequence: On a weekly basis: Continuously scan, identify an opportunity, and run a fast experiment.
On a quarterly basis: Pause to hold a formal 'Synthesis & Strategy' session. Analyze the results of all experiments from the past quarter to update the team's core strategic thesis.

activity_citation.citation_text: Ries, E. (2011). The Lean Startup. Crown Business.
activity_citation.rationale: This pathway operationalizes the "Build-Measure-Learn" loop of the Lean Startup. The weekly cycle is the core loop, and the quarterly synthesis is a higher-level loop for strategic learning, ensuring that the rapid experiments are not just tactical but are contributing to a coherent strategy.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Scan environment
Identify opportunity
Assess strategic fit
Create an experimental plan

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: Seeley, W. W., et al. (2007). Dissociable intrinsic connectivity networks for salience processing and executive control. Journal of Neuroscience, 27(9), 2349-2556.
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: This sequence is a classic model of opportunity detection. The `DAN` is engaged for broad scanning. The `SN` detects a salient opportunity. The `vmPFC` assesses its value, and the `ECN` creates a plan to act on it.

content.title: The Backlog Refinement Path
content.summary: Review with Purpose -> Estimate -> Prepare
content.rationale: A continuous planning process, improved with a 'micro-ritual' of purpose to prevent it from becoming a tedious, administrative chore.
activity_sequence: Hold a regular backlog refinement meeting.
For each high-priority story, the Product Owner must first articulate the 'Why, Who, What': Why is this important, Who is it for, and What core problem does it solve?
With this context established, the team then adds technical details and estimates.

activity_citation.citation_text: This pathway describes the Backlog Refinement (or "Grooming") ceremony, a core practice within the Scrum framework.
activity_citation.rationale: The authority comes from the established, widespread practice of the Scrum methodology. The "Review with Purpose" step is a best practice addition to ensure the ceremony remains focused on value, not just tasks.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Review the product backlog
Estimate effort and value for top items
Negotiate priorities with stakeholders
Prepare a "ready" backlog for the next sprint

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: This is a plausible synthesis of known network functions for this agile ceremony. Reviewing the backlog involves memory and executive control (`Hippo`, `ECN`). Estimation is a value-based judgment (`vmPFC`). Negotiation is a social task (`SCN`). Preparing the final backlog is a core executive function (`ECN`).
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: The sequence represents a robust model of the cognitive steps involved in backlog refinement, integrating memory, valuation, social cognition, and executive control.

content.title: The Resource Allocation Path
content.summary: Constrain -> Prioritize Scope -> Plan
content.rationale: A top-down financial planning process, improved by making 'scope' the explicit flexible variable to prevent 'death march' projects.
activity_sequence: Start with a fixed budget and deadline.
Collaboratively prioritize the scope into a 'must-have' core and a ranked list of 'nice-to-have' features.
Create a plan that guarantees the delivery of the 'must-have' core. The plan is successful if it delivers the core on time and on budget, even if not all nice-to-haves are completed.

activity_citation.citation_text: This pathway describes the core principles of traditional project management (PMP) and financial planning, often referred to as the "iron triangle" (Scope, Time, Cost).
activity_citation.rationale: The authority comes from the foundational principles of project management. The pathway's innovation is to explicitly fix Time and Cost and make Scope the variable, which is a key principle of agile adaptation applied to a traditional model.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Define the budget and timeline
Imagine what's possible within constraints
Assess risk vs. reward
Create a high-level project plan

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: This is a classic model of constrained planning. The `ECN` holds the constraints. The `DMN` imagines possibilities within those constraints. The `vmPFC` evaluates the options, and the `ECN` creates the final plan.
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: The sequence is a direct application of the known functions of the brain's executive, imaginative, and valuation networks in a planning context.

content.title: The Bet-Driven Path
content.summary: Identify Assumptions -> Rank by Risk -> Design Test
content.rationale: For high-uncertainty projects, improved with a mandatory prioritization step to ensure the team tests the most fundamental assumptions first.
activity_sequence: List every assumption that must be true for the business model to succeed.
Force-rank these assumptions, asking 'Which one, if proven false, would cause the entire venture to fail?' This is your Riskiest Assumption.
Design the smallest, cheapest, fastest possible experiment to rigorously test only that single, riskiest assumption.

activity_citation.citation_text: Blank, S. (2013). The Four Steps to the Epiphany. K&S Ranch.
activity_citation.rationale: This is a foundational text of the Lean Startup movement. The pathway's method of identifying and testing the riskiest assumption first is the core principle of Blank's customer development methodology.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Identify key uncertainties
Frame them as "bets" with testable hypotheses
Assess the cost of being wrong
Create a plan to run multiple, parallel, low-cost experiments

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: This is a plausible synthesis of known network functions for risk-based planning. Identifying uncertainties is an imaginative task (`DMN`). Framing them as hypotheses is an executive function (`ECN`). Assessing the cost of failure involves emotional and value-based judgment (`Amygdala`, `vmPFC`). Creating the final plan is a core executive function (`ECN`).
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: The sequence represents a robust model of the cognitive steps involved in de-risking a new venture, integrating imagination, executive control, and emotional valuation.

content.title: The Alignment Path
content.summary: Define Signals -> Sense -> Align
content.rationale: An adaptive process of sensing and aligning, improved by making the 'sensing' step a concrete, collaborative process of defining observable signals.
activity_sequence: First, collaboratively define a small set of observable, qualitative signals that represent the 'health' or 'flow' of the system (e.g., team morale, stakeholder engagement).
Actively 'sense' these signals through observation and deep listening.
Design a plan that aligns with and leverages the existing flows of energy and momentum.

activity_citation.citation_text: This pathway is an application of the Daoist concept of Strategic Alignment (effortless action).
activity_citation.rationale: The authority comes from a foundational concept in Daoist philosophy. The pathway operationalizes this ancient integrated knowledge by providing a structured method for sensing the "flow" of a system and aligning with it, rather than trying to force a plan upon it.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Sense the "flow" of the system
Identify key signals
Feel the path of least resistance
Align the plan with the flow

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: Craig, A. D. (2009). How do you feel-now? The anterior insula and human awareness. Nature Reviews Neuroscience, 10(1), 59-70.
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: This sequence models an intuitive, adaptive form of planning. The `DAN` is engaged for broad, receptive awareness. The `SN` detects the key signals. The `Insula` provides the interoceptive "felt sense" of the path of least resistance, which then guides the `ECN`'s final plan. Craig's work on the insula provides the grounding for this crucial "felt sense" step.

content.title: The Precautionary Path
content.summary: Imagine a Harm Persona -> Consult -> Safeguard
content.rationale: Prioritizes harm prevention, improved by making the imaginative act more concrete and emotionally resonant through narrative.
activity_sequence: Create a detailed 'Harm Persona' of a specific individual or group who is most vulnerable to your project's unintended consequences. Write a short, vivid story of how your project could lead to a disastrous outcome for them.
Consult with real stakeholders who share characteristics with your Harm Persona to validate your understanding.
Design specific, robust safeguards into your project plan that would protect your Harm Persona from the story you wrote.

activity_citation.citation_text: The pathway is a practical application of the 'Precautionary Principle,' as defined in the 1992 Rio Declaration on Environment and Development.
activity_citation.rationale: The Rio Declaration is an authoritative international document that provides the most widely accepted definition of the Precautionary Principle. The "Harm Persona" is a design thinking technique applied here to make the abstract principle concrete and actionable.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Imagine potential harms
Consult with vulnerable stakeholders
Regulate desire for progress
Build safeguards into the plan

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: Buckner, R. L., & Carroll, D. C. (2007). Self-projection and the brain. Trends in Cognitive Sciences, 11(2), 49-57.
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: This paper establishes the role of the DMN in imagining future scenarios ("prospection"). The pathway's first step of imagining potential harms is a direct application of this DMN function. The subsequent steps of social consultation (`SCN`), value-based regulation (`vmPFC`), and planning (`ECN`) represent the integration of this imaginative act with social and executive functions.

content.title: The Principles Path
content.summary: Articulate -> Operationalize -> Embody
content.rationale: Grounds the plan in non-negotiable principles, improved by translating abstract values into concrete, observable behaviors.
activity_sequence: Co-create a short list of guiding principles.

Operationalize each principle by creating a corresponding 'If/Then' behavioral protocol (e.g., Principle: 'We are transparent.' Protocol: 'If we make a decision that affects another team, then we must inform them within 24 hours.').
The project plan is then built upon a commitment to embody these specific, observable protocols.

activity_citation.citation_text: Beck, K., et al. (2001). Manifesto for Agile Software Development.
activity_citation.rationale: This pathway is a direct application of the structure of the Agile Manifesto, which is built on a set of core values followed by 12 supporting, operational principles. This provides a proven and authoritative model for creating a principle-based plan.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Co-create a set of guiding principles
Articulate them clearly
Commit to them emotionally
The "plan" is to continually check actions against these principles

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: This is a plausible synthesis of known network functions. Co-creating principles is a social and imaginative task (`SCN`, `DMN`). The final step of continually checking actions against these principles is a classic model of cognitive control, where the `ECN` holds the rules and the `ACC` monitors for violations.
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: The sequence represents a robust model of the cognitive steps involved in value-based planning, integrating social, imaginative, and executive brain networks.

content.title: The Slow Path
content.summary: Prime -> Incubate -> Harvest
content.rationale: Intentionally slows down planning to allow for deeper insight, improved by making the process an active, intentional cognitive workflow.
activity_sequence: Hold a short 'priming' session: Clearly articulate the single, complex question you are hoping to gain insight on during the planning phase.
Deliberately pause the planning process and engage in unrelated, low-cognitive-load activities to allow for subconscious incubation.
Reconvene for a 'gentle harvest' to share any emergent strategic insights or connections that arose during the pause.

activity_citation.citation_text: Kahneman, D. (2011). Thinking, Fast and Slow. Farrar, Straus and Giroux.
activity_citation.rationale: This pathway is a practical application of Kahneman's "System 2" or "slow thinking." By deliberately creating a period of incubation, it allows the brain's non-conscious, associative networks (System 1) to work on the problem in the background, leading to deeper insights than effortful, conscious thought alone.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Define the inquiry
Schedule a period of incubation/rest
Allow for subconscious processing
Harvest the emergent plan

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: Beaty, R. E., et al. (2016). Creative cognition and brain network dynamics. Trends in Cognitive Sciences, 20(2), 87-95.
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: This sequence is a direct application of the neuroscientific model of creative incubation. The `ECN` defines the problem and then actively inhibits itself to allow the `DMN` to engage in free-form, associative thought. The `SN` then detects a novel, useful connection, which the `ECN` brings into conscious awareness to formalize as a plan.

content.title: The Symbolic Prompting Path
content.summary: Pose -> Constrain -> Brainstorm
content.rationale: Uses a symbolic system to orient the project, reframed in the language of cognitive science to make it a rigorous tool for breaking fixed mindsets. This is not about predicting the future, but about using a random semantic constraint to force the ECN and DMN to find novel connections.
activity_sequence: Pose a strategic planning question you are stuck on.
Generate a random symbolic constraint by drawing a card or using a similar tool.

Do not treat the symbol as an answer. Instead, use it as a prompt for a structured brainstorming session: 'How is our strategic problem like this symbol? What new planning approaches does this metaphor suggest?'

activity_citation.citation_text: Eno, B., & Schmidt, P. (1975). Oblique Strategies: Over One Hundred Worthwhile Dilemmas.
activity_citation.rationale: This is the direct source for this pathway. Oblique Strategies is a card-based system designed to break creative blocks by introducing a random, often cryptic, constraint. This pathway formalizes that artistic practice into a strategic planning tool.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Engage with a symbolic system (e.g., tarot, I Ching)
Interpret the symbolic output
Notice personal significance
Create a plan inspired by the interpretation

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: This is a speculative but plausible neurocognitive model. The engagement with the symbolic system is a physical act (`Sensorimotor`). The interpretation of the symbol is a highly associative, meaning-making task (`DMN`). The "felt sense" of significance is an interoceptive signal (`Insula`), which then guides the `ECN` to create a plan.
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: While the process is non-traditional, the underlying cognitive steps are consistent with known brain functions for perception, meaning-making, and planning.

content.title: The Bio-Empathy Path
content.summary: Research -> Empathize -> Serve
content.rationale: Orients the project by taking a non-human perspective, improved by grounding the empathetic act in rigorous scientific research.
activity_sequence: Choose a non-human stakeholder for your project (e.g., a local watershed).
Begin by rigorously researching the scientific realities of this stakeholder. Treat the ecological and biological data as the 'voice' of the stakeholder that you must first listen to.
With this scientific understanding as a foundation, engage in a perspective-taking exercise.
Design a project plan where a primary success criterion is the measurable improvement of the stakeholder's ecological health.

activity_citation.citation_text: Kimmerer, R. W. (2013). Braiding Sweetgrass: Indigenous Culture, Scientific Knowledge and the Teachings of Plants. Milkweed Editions.
activity_citation.rationale: This is a key text that beautifully articulates an Indigenous worldview that integrates scientific and traditional ways of knowing. The pathway's method of combining rigorous scientific research with an empathetic, relational stance toward the non-human world is a direct application of the principles Kimmerer describes.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Take the perspective of a non-human entity
Imagine its needs and goals
Feel empathetic concern
Create a plan that serves its interests

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: This is a speculative but plausible application of the Social Cognition Network (`SCN`). It hypothesizes that the brain's capacity for "Theory of Mind" can be extended to non-human entities, allowing us to model their "interests." This imaginative act (`DMN`) can then generate an empathetic response (`Limbic`) that guides a formal plan (`ECN`).
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: While speculative, this model is grounded in the known flexibility of the SCN and DMN for abstract and imaginative thought.

content.title: The 'Exemplar' Path
content.summary: Sense Planning Block -> Find a Similar Plan -> Use as Template
content.rationale: A targeted intervention for the DLS state 'known-correct-now-but-not-recalled' (Planning Block). It provides an external cognitive scaffold (the exemplar) to reactivate forgotten procedural knowledge for planning.
activity_sequence: Acknowledge the difficulty in starting the plan from a blank page.
Find a high-quality example of a similar plan or document.
Use the exemplar's structure as a template, replacing its content with your own project's details.

activity_citation.citation_text: This pathway is derived from the principles of scaffolding and worked examples in cognitive load theory.
activity_citation.rationale: The authority comes from a well-established body of research in educational psychology. Providing learners with a "worked example" or exemplar is a proven method for reducing cognitive load and helping them build a schema for a new type of problem.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Sense a 'planning block' as a cognitive conflict between the goal (create plan) and a failure to retrieve a procedural schema.
Shift from internal memory search to an external, visual search for a suitable exemplar.
Analytically deconstruct the exemplar's hierarchical structure into its component parts and rules.
Hold the extracted structure (the 'template') in working memory.
Apply the template by retrieving the new project's content and systematically filling in the scaffold, reducing cognitive load.

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: This is a plausible synthesis of known network functions. The initial conflict (`ACC`), external search (`DAN`), deconstruction (`Parietal Lobe`), and application (`ECN`) are all well-supported by cognitive neuroscience.
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: The sequence represents a robust model of how an external scaffold can be used to overcome a cognitive block, grounded in the known functions of the brain's attentional, executive, and analytical networks.

content.title: The 'After Action Review' Path
content.summary: Sense Potential for Repeated Error -> Review Past Flawed Plan -> Explicitly Mitigate in New Plan
content.rationale: A targeted intervention for the DLS state 'unknown-now-but-previously-known-incorrectly...' (Repeating Past Planning Mistakes). It forces a deliberate review of a past failure to prevent the repetition of a flawed structural pattern.
activity_sequence: If the current planning process feels uncomfortably similar to a past failure, pause.
Retrieve the documentation from the past failed project.
Conduct an 'After Action Review,' identifying the specific planning assumption or structural flaw that led to the failure.
Explicitly add a step or constraint to the new plan that mitigates this specific flaw.

activity_citation.citation_text: U.S. Army. (1993). A Leader's Guide to After-Action Reviews (Training Circular 25-20).
activity_citation.rationale: This is the original, authoritative source that codified the After-Action Review (AAR) process. The pathway's method of systematically reviewing a past event to learn from it is a direct application of the AAR methodology, which is a highly validated process for organizational learning.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Sense an intuitive risk or feeling of 'déjà vu' that the current plan is flawed.
Initiate a deliberate retrieval of a specific past plan that failed.
Perform a causal analysis on the old plan, replaying the memory of its failure to identify the specific structural flaw.
Formulate a new, explicit rule designed to prevent that specific flaw.
Hold this new rule as a constraint while finalizing the new plan, ensuring the past error is explicitly mitigated.

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: This is a plausible synthesis of known network functions for learning from failure. The initial intuitive risk detection (`ACC`, `Insula`), memory retrieval and replay (`Hippo`, `DMN`), and the use of the `ECN` to abstract a new rule and apply inhibitory control are all well-supported by cognitive and affective neuroscience.
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: The sequence represents a robust model of metacognitive learning from past mistakes, integrating intuition, memory, and executive control.

content.title: The Political Buy-In Path
content.summary: Map Stakeholders -> Identify Key Influencers -> Co-create the Plan -> Secure Buy-in
content.rationale: A strategic pathway that uses stakeholder mapping not for discovery, but as a political and logistical tool. It ensures a project plan is not only technically sound but also has the necessary social and organizational support to succeed by proactively identifying dependencies and securing buy-in from key influencers.
activity_sequence: Conduct a Stakeholder Mapping (N03) exercise, focusing on influence and interest.
Identify the 1-3 key individuals whose support is critical for the plan's success.
Schedule individual or small-group sessions with these key stakeholders to get their feedback and incorporate their needs into the plan.
Present the final, co-created plan for formal approval.

activity_citation.citation_text: This pathway is derived from the principles of organizational change management and corporate strategy. A specific citation is less relevant than its validation through widespread, successful practice in large organizations.
activity_citation.rationale: The authority comes from established best practices in corporate strategy and change management. The sequence of mapping stakeholders, identifying influencers, and co-opting them into the planning process is a standard and effective method for ensuring a project's political viability.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Identify all stakeholders and map their influence and interest
Identify the key decision-makers and potential blockers
Engage key stakeholders in a co-creation process to build ownership
Formalize the plan and secure official buy-in

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: Saxe, R., & Kanwisher, N. (2003). People thinking about thinking people: The role of the temporo-parietal junction in 'theory of mind'. NeuroImage, 19(4), 1835-1842.
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: This entire sequence is a high-level application of the Social Cognition Network (`SCN`). Mapping influence, identifying key players, and engaging in co-creation are all complex social-cognitive tasks that rely on the brain's ability to model the minds, intentions, and power dynamics of other people.

content.title: The Scaffolding Path
content.summary: Define Success -> Model the Process -> Co-create the Plan
content.rationale: This pathway makes the expert's tacit knowledge visible. It begins by making the goal explicit, then the facilitator performs a 'think-aloud' demonstration of the planning process, and finally, they guide the learner in creating their own plan. This systematically reduces cognitive load and builds learner independence, aligning with Vygotsky's Zone of Proximal Development.
activity_sequence: Co-create a clear 'Definition of Done' or rubric with the learners.
Model the process of creating a plan (e.g., a concept map or outline) while explaining your thinking at each step.
Facilitate a workshop where learners create their own plans, providing targeted support and feedback as needed.

activity_citation.citation_text: Vygotsky, L. S. (1978). Mind in Society: The Development of Higher Psychological Processes. Harvard University Press.
activity_citation.rationale: This is the foundational text for the concept of the "Zone of Proximal Development" (ZPD) and "scaffolding." The pathway's sequence of modeling a process and then providing guided support is a direct application of Vygotsky's theory of how learning occurs through social interaction with a more knowledgeable other.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Define Success
Perform a 'think-aloud' while executing a task, externalizing metacognition
Guide the learner's planning process with responsive prompts

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: This is a plausible synthesis of known network functions for teaching. Defining success is an executive and linguistic task (`ECN`, `Lang`). The "think-aloud" is a complex act of performing a task while simultaneously modeling another's perspective (`SCN`). Guiding the learner is a social-cognitive feedback loop (`SCN`, `ECN`).
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: The sequence represents a robust model of the cognitive steps involved in expert pedagogical scaffolding, integrating executive control, social cognition, and language.

content.title: The Research Path
content.summary: Review -> Challenge Assumptions -> Identify -> Detail
content.rationale: Maximizes rigor and builds on established knowledge, improved to encourage transformative, paradigm-challenging questions rather than purely incremental ones.
activity_sequence: Conduct a literature review to articulate the field's dominant paradigm.
Explicitly list the core, unstated assumptions of that paradigm and select one to challenge.
Identify a high-risk, high-reward research question that directly tests that core assumption.
Create a detailed project plan to investigate this transformative question.

activity_citation.citation_text: Popper, K. R. (1959). The Logic of Scientific Discovery. Hutchinson.
activity_citation.rationale: This pathway is a direct application of Popper's principle of falsification. The mandatory step of identifying and challenging a core assumption is a structured method for generating the kind of bold, falsifiable hypotheses that Popper argued are the engine of scientific progress.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Access prior knowledge
Hold goal in working memory
Identify gap in literature
Create linear plan to fill gap

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: Squire, L. R., & Kandel, E. R. (2009). Memory: From Mind to Molecules. Roberts and Company Publishers.
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: This keystone textbook provides the foundational evidence for the role of the Hippocampus in retrieving semantic memory (prior knowledge). The subsequent steps of using the ECN to hold this information, identify gaps, and create a plan are a classic model of executive function in a research context.

content.title: The Feasibility Path
content.summary: Define -> Test -> Assess Impact -> Plan
content.rationale: De-risks ambitious projects by testing the hardest part first, enhanced with a mandatory ethical and systemic impact review to ensure 'Can we?' is followed by 'Should we?'.
activity_sequence: Define the project's core objective and its most critical technical assumption.
Build a 'sacrificial prototype' to test only that single assumption as quickly as possible.
Hold a formal 'Impact Review' to assess the ethical and systemic consequences of the prototype's success.
Create a formal project plan that incorporates both the technical results and the impact assessment.

activity_citation.citation_text: Ries, E. (2011). The Lean Startup. Crown Business.
activity_citation.rationale: The core of this pathway—identifying the riskiest assumption and testing it with a minimal prototype—is a direct application of the Lean Startup methodology. The "Impact Review" is an ethical layer added from the Responsible Innovation literature.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Define goal
Build a quick proof-of-concept
Notice unexpected constraints/opportunities
Create a plan based on feasibility

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: Schön, D. A. (1983). The Reflective Practitioner. Basic Books.
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: This sequence models Schön's concept of a "conversation with the materials." The practitioner defines a goal (`ECN`), acts in the world (`Sensorimotor`), notices the material's response (`SN`), and then adapts their plan (`ECN`). This provides a strong theoretical basis for this iterative, learning-focused approach.

content.title: The Systems Modeling Path
content.summary: Map -> Validate with Stakeholders -> Simulate -> Intervene
content.rationale: For complex systems where linear plans fail, improved by ensuring the model is validated against the lived reality of the people within the system.
activity_sequence: Create a draft concept map or system diagram of all interacting parts.
Present this draft map to stakeholders within the system for feedback and collaboratively revise it to reflect their lived reality.
Mentally (or computationally) simulate how the validated system behaves over time.
Identify the point of highest leverage and design a plan for intervention.

activity_citation.citation_text: Meadows, D. H. (2008). Thinking in Systems: A Primer. Chelsea Green Publishing.
activity_citation.rationale: This is the foundational text for systems thinking. The pathway's sequence of mapping a system, simulating its behavior, and identifying leverage points is the core methodology that Meadows outlines. The "Validate with Stakeholders" step is an addition from participatory action research.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Map the system's components
Simulate system dynamics
Identify leverage points
Create a plan to intervene at a leverage point

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: Buckner, R. L., & Carroll, D. C. (2007). Self-projection and the brain. Trends in Cognitive Sciences, 11(2), 49-57.
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: This paper's description of the DMN's role in simulating future scenarios provides the direct neurocognitive basis for the "Simulate" step. The initial mapping is a focused, external task (`DAN`), and the final planning step is a classic executive function (`ECN`).

content.title: The Requirements-Driven Path
content.summary: Gather -> Reframe as Hypotheses -> Test -> Codify
content.rationale: Standard for contract engineering, updated to integrate a lean, experimental mindset that guards against building the wrong thing perfectly.
activity_sequence: Gather initial stakeholder needs and requests.
Translate each 'requirement' into a falsifiable hypothesis (e.g., 'We believe that feature X will lead to outcome Y').
Identify the riskiest hypothesis and run a quick experiment to validate it.
Use the learnings from the experiment to write a more robust and validated formal requirements document.

activity_citation.citation_text: This pathway represents a synthesis of traditional Waterfall project management (gathering requirements upfront) and Lean Startup principles (treating requirements as hypotheses).
activity_citation.rationale: The authority comes from the synthesis of two major, though often opposed, project management philosophies. This hybrid approach is a best practice in modern, agile-at-scale environments.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Gather stakeholder requirements
Translate needs into technical specs
Negotiate trade-offs
Create a work breakdown structure

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: This is a plausible synthesis of known network functions. Gathering requirements is a social task (`SCN`). Translating them into a spec is a linguistic and executive task (`Lang`, `ECN`). Negotiating trade-offs is a value-based judgment (`vmPFC`). Creating the final plan is a core executive function (`ECN`).
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: The sequence represents a robust model of the cognitive steps involved in translating human needs into a technical plan, grounded in the known functions of the brain's social, executive, and valuation networks.

content.title: The Patent Review Path
content.summary: Articulate -> Search -> Mine for Inspiration -> Navigate
content.rationale: Essential for commercial R&D, transformed from a purely defensive legal exercise into a generative source of inspiration.
activity_sequence: Clearly articulate the core mechanism of the proposed invention.
Conduct a thorough review of existing patents ('prior art').

Mine the search results for inspiration: Identify 1-3 blocking patents that contain a clever mechanism and brainstorm how that mechanism could be adapted to create a superior, non-infringing solution.
Create a research plan that navigates the IP landscape by leveraging these insights.

activity_citation.citation_text: This pathway is derived from the standard operating procedures of corporate R&D and intellectual property law.
activity_citation.rationale: The authority comes from established professional practice. The process of conducting a prior art search is a mandatory step in any patent application process. The "Mine for Inspiration" step is an innovative addition from creativity literature.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Define the proposed solution
Scan the patent landscape
Detect potential infringement (conflict)
Design a plan to navigate or innovate around existing IP

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: Botvinick, M. M., et al. (2001). Conflict monitoring and cognitive control. Psychological Review, 108(3), 624-652.
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: The core of this sequence is the detection of a conflict (`ACC`) between the proposed solution and existing prior art. This conflict signal then engages the ECN and DMN to formulate a new, innovative plan that avoids the conflict, a classic model of creative problem-solving under constraint.

content.title: The Frontier Path
content.summary: Explore -> Understand -> Narrate -> Formulate
content.rationale: Used in completely novel fields, improved with a 'narrative synthesis' step to bridge the gap between tacit, embodied understanding and a formal plan.
activity_sequence: Engage in open-ended, exploratory experimentation.
Develop an intuitive, embodied understanding of the core dynamics.
Synthesize this tacit understanding into a compelling 'explorer's narrative' that describes the journey, the key discoveries, and the central mystery that has emerged.
Use this narrative as the foundation to formulate a formal research plan.

activity_citation.citation_text: This pathway describes the initial, pre-paradigmatic phase of scientific inquiry as described by Thomas Kuhn in The Structure of Scientific Revolutions (1962).
activity_citation.rationale: Kuhn's work is the authoritative source for understanding how new scientific fields emerge. This pathway codifies the messy, exploratory process that precedes the establishment of "normal science," where narrative and intuition play a key role.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Explore a new space
Get a 'feel' for it
Form initial impressions
Formulate a plan based on direct experience

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: Varela, F. J., Thompson, E., & Rosch, E. (1991). The Embodied Mind: Cognitive Science and Human Experience. MIT Press.
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: This is a foundational text for Embodied Cognition. The pathway's sequence of learning through direct physical exploration (`Sensorimotor`) to develop an intuitive "feel" that then guides a formal plan (`ECN`) is a direct application of the principles of embodied and enactive cognition.

content.title: The Scholarly Path
content.summary: Survey -> Situate Self & Argument -> Outline
content.rationale: Situates one's own argument within an ongoing conversation, improved to include a mandatory reflection on the researcher's own positionality.
activity_sequence: Survey the scholarly conversation to understand the major schools of thought.
Conduct a 'Positionality Mapping' exercise to situate your own perspective and identify an authentic, meaningful contribution.
Use this situated understanding to outline your unique argument.

activity_citation.citation_text: Graff, G., & Birkenstein, C. (2010). They Say / I Say: The Moves That Matter in Academic Writing. W. W. Norton & Company.
activity_citation.rationale: This is a foundational text for academic writing. The pathway's method of starting by surveying the existing conversation ("They Say") and then situating one's own contribution ("I Say") is the core model that Graff and Birkenstein advocate.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Conduct historiography
Map the debate
Identify a niche for contribution
Outline your argument

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: This is a plausible synthesis of known network functions for scholarly work. The initial review of literature involves memory retrieval (`Hippo`, `DMN`). Mapping the debate is a structured, analytical task (`ECN`). Noticing a gap is a salience detection function (`SN`), and outlining is a core executive function (`ECN`).
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: The sequence represents a robust model of the cognitive steps involved in academic planning, grounded in the known functions of the brain's memory, executive, and salience networks.

content.title: The Archival Path
content.summary: Immerse -> Synthesize -> Repeat
content.rationale: A discovery-driven process where the argument emerges from evidence, improved with an iterative structure to prevent aimless 'data hoarding'.
activity_sequence: Conduct a short, time-boxed period of immersion in the archive.
Pause to synthesize and thematically code the findings from that period.
Use these insights to define the focus for the next period of immersion.
Repeat this cycle until a coherent research plan emerges.

activity_citation.citation_text: This pathway codifies the core methodology of archival history and data-driven sociology.
activity_citation.rationale: The authority comes from the established practice of these academic disciplines. The iterative cycle of immersion in primary sources followed by a period of synthesis is the standard, validated workflow for historians and qualitative sociologists.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Explore an archive/dataset
Discover a key piece of evidence
Connect it to a broader narrative
Build a research plan around it

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: Seeley, W. W., et al. (2007). Dissociable intrinsic connectivity networks for salience processing and executive control. Journal of Neuroscience, 27(9), 2349-2556.
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: This sequence is a classic example of discovery. The researcher explores the data with focused attention (`DAN`). The Salience Network (`SN`) flags a particularly interesting or anomalous piece of evidence. This triggers the DMN to connect this evidence to a larger story, and the ECN to build a formal plan around this new insight.

content.title: The Methodological Path
content.summary: Survey -> Juxtapose Lenses -> Synthesize
content.rationale: Focuses on choosing the right theoretical lens, improved by transforming the path from a monologic application into A Structured comparison of competing theories.
activity_sequence: Survey the available theoretical lenses.
Select two lenses that offer competing or complementary perspectives on the research question.
Create a plan to analyze the object of study through both lenses, noting where they converge and diverge.
The final plan is to synthesize an original argument from the tension between the two.

activity_citation.citation_text: This pathway is derived from the standard practice for graduate-level research proposals in the social sciences and humanities.
activity_citation.rationale: The authority comes from the established pedagogical practices of higher education. The process of surveying, selecting, and justifying a theoretical framework is a core requirement of any Ph.D. prospectus or dissertation proposal.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Review theoretical frameworks
Select the most appropriate lens
Inhibit other lenses
Design a research plan using that method

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: Damasio, A. R. (1994). Descartes' Error. Putnam.
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: The selection of a theoretical lens is not a purely logical choice; it is a value-based judgment about which perspective is most "interesting" or "powerful." Damasio's work on the role of the vmPFC in value-based decision-making provides the neurocognitive grounding for this crucial selection step, which then guides the ECN's planning process.

content.title: The Ethical Review Path
content.summary: Draft -> Mitigate -> Plan for Reciprocity -> Submit
content.rationale: Essential for any research involving human subjects, expanded beyond harm reduction to include a positive obligation to create benefit for the participant community.
activity_sequence: Draft a preliminary research plan and identify potential risks.
Design mitigation strategies for those risks.
Develop a concrete 'Reciprocity & Benefit Plan' that outlines how the research will provide direct, tangible value back to the participant community.
Submit the complete plan, including both risk mitigation and benefit creation, for formal ethical review.

activity_citation.citation_text: National Commission for the Protection of Human Subjects of Biomedical and Behavioral Research. (1979). The Belmont Report.
activity_citation.rationale: This is the foundational document that established the ethical principles (Respect for Persons, Beneficence, Justice) that govern all research with human subjects in the United States. The pathway's sequence is a direct operationalization of these principles and the formal Institutional Review Board (IRB) process that enforces them.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Draft a preliminary research plan
Imagine potential harms to participants
Regulate desire to get data quickly
Write an ethical review (IRB) protocol

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: Greene, J. D., et al. (2001). An fMRI investigation of emotional engagement in moral judgment. Science, 293(5537), 2105-2108.
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: This sequence is a model of applied ethical reasoning. It involves imagining the perspective of others (`DMN`, `SCN`), engaging in value-based regulation (`vmPFC`), and translating those ethical considerations into a formal, rule-based plan (`ECN`). Greene's work on the interplay between emotion and reason in moral judgment provides a strong neuroscientific basis for this process.

content.title: The Positional Path
content.summary: Reflect -> Articulate -> Audit for Bias
content.rationale: A critical practice that grounds research by making biases explicit, improved by making the 'adjustment' step a concrete, auditable task.
activity_sequence: Engage in self-reflection about your social position.
Write a formal 'positionality statement' that makes potential biases explicit.
Conduct a 'Bias Audit': Create a document that explicitly links aspects of your positionality to specific, concrete adjustments in your research plan (e.g., question wording, recruitment strategy).

activity_citation.citation_text: Haraway, D. (1988). Situated Knowledges: The Science Question in Feminism and the Privilege of Partial Perspective. Feminist Studies, 14(3), 575-599.
activity_citation.rationale: This is a cornerstone text for the concept of "Positionality." Haraway's argument that all knowledge is "situated" and that acknowledging one's partial perspective is a requirement for objectivity provides the philosophical justification for this entire pathway.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Reflect on own identity and biases
Experience associated emotions
Articulate positionality
Adjust research plan to account for biases

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: This is a plausible synthesis of known network functions for self-reflection and planning. The reflection on identity involves self-referential thought and memory retrieval (`DMN`, `Hippo`). The adjustment of the plan is a classic executive function (`ECN`).
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: The sequence represents a robust model of metacognitive self-correction, grounded in the known functions of the brain's self-referential, emotional, and executive networks.

content.title: The Community Co-Design Path
content.summary: Establish Governance -> Convene -> Co-create
content.rationale: Radically shifts power by designing the research plan *with* the community, improved by making the negotiation of power the mandatory first step.
activity_sequence: Work with community representatives to establish a formal governance model for the project, clarifying decision-making power, data ownership, and resource allocation.
Convene the broader community within this established governance structure.
Facilitate a process where the community, exercising its defined power, directs the creation of the research plan.

activity_citation.citation_text: Fals Borda, O. (1987). The Problem of Investigating Reality in Order to Transform it. Dialectical Anthropology, 12(1), 33-55.
activity_citation.rationale: This is a foundational text for Participatory Action Research (PAR). The pathway's method of establishing a co-equal governance structure with the community before the research even begins is a direct application of the most rigorous and ethically advanced forms of PAR.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Facilitate a community goal-setting session
Listen without imposing own agenda
Co-create the research plan
Formalize the shared plan

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: Hasson, U., et al. (2012). Brain-to-brain coupling: a mechanism for creating and sharing a social world. Trends in Cognitive Sciences, 16(2), 114-121.
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: This keystone review on "inter-brain synchrony" provides the neurocognitive grounding for this highly collaborative pathway. The entire sequence is an exercise in deep social cognition (`SCN`), requiring the facilitator to inhibit their own agenda (`ECN inhibition`) and achieve a state of neural coupling with the group to co-create a shared plan.

content.title: The Divergent Path
content.summary: Generate -> Group -> Select a Portfolio
content.rationale: The classic brainstorming model, improved by reframing the goal from 'picking a winner' to 'building a strategic portfolio' to better handle uncertainty.
activity_sequence: Generate a high volume of ideas without judgment.
Group and theme the ideas.
Instead of selecting a single 'winner,' select a balanced portfolio of ideas to explore further (e.g., one 'Safe Bet,' one 'Ambitious Bet,' and one 'Long Shot').

activity_citation.citation_text: This pathway codifies the "Diverge/Converge" model, a core principle of Design Thinking, as popularized by the Stanford d.school.
activity_citation.rationale: The authority comes from the established, widespread practice of the Design Thinking methodology. The "Select a Portfolio" step is an addition from strategic management that improves the robustness of the final convergence.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Divergent ideation (no judgment)
Inhibit the inner critic
Apply constraints and filter
Select novel variants

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: Beaty, R. E., et al. (2016). Creative cognition and brain network dynamics. Trends in Cognitive Sciences, 20(2), 87-95.
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: This key paper provides the neuroscientific evidence for the interplay between the DMN and ECN during creative thought. The pathway's sequence of divergent generation (`DMN`), inhibition of judgment (`ECN`), and final evaluation (`ECN`, `SN`) is a direct application of the cognitive model described in this authoritative review.

content.title: The Accidental Path
content.summary: Predict -> Play -> Notice Deviation -> Develop
content.rationale: Leverages serendipity to discover ideas, improved by adding a 'Prediction' step that primes the brain to more reliably notice 'happy accidents'.
activity_sequence: Before experimenting, state a simple, clear prediction of what you expect the material or process to do.
Engage in the experimentation or play.
Pay close attention to any 'prediction errors'—moments where the outcome deviates from your expectation. These are your 'happy accidents.'
Select the most interesting deviation to develop.

activity_citation.citation_text: This pathway codifies a common discovery process for painters, sculptors, and musicians.
activity_citation.rationale: The authority comes from the documented practices of countless artists. The "Prediction" step is an addition from cognitive science (Predictive Processing) to make this often-tacit process more reliable.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Engage in mindless play with materials
Notice an interesting accident
Feel its aesthetic potential
Develop the accident into a formal concept

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: Friston, K. (2010). The free-energy principle: a unified brain theory? Nature Reviews Neuroscience, 11(2), 127-138.
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: This pathway is a direct application of the Predictive Processing theory. The "happy accident" is a "prediction error." The brain's Salience Network (`SN`) is hardwired to detect such errors, which then triggers an update to the mental model (`ECN`) and a feeling of interest (`Insula`).

content.title: The Transformative Path
content.summary: Define Intent -> Select -> Modify -> Develop
content.rationale: Creates new ideas by re-contextualizing existing ones, improved by adding a mandatory 'Define Intent' step to ensure the novelty serves a clear purpose.
activity_sequence: First, articulate a clear strategic intent for the transformation (e.g., 'Our goal is to make this process more inclusive').
Select a familiar object or idea to transform.
Use a structured method like SCAMPER, using your strategic intent as a filter for which modifications to explore.
Select and develop the transformation that best achieves the original intent.

activity_citation.citation_text: Eberle, B. (1996). SCAMPER: Games for Imagination Development. Prufrock Press.
activity_citation.rationale: This is the canonical text that developed the SCAMPER mnemonic. The pathway's method of systematically applying transformative operations to an existing idea is a direct application of the SCAMPER technique.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Select an existing object or idea
Apply a transformative operation (e.g., scale, combine, reverse)
Assess the novelty of the result
Develop the transformed idea into a full concept

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: This is a plausible synthesis of known network functions. The sequence involves memory retrieval (`Hippo`), focused attention (`DAN`), creative combination (`DMN`), salience detection (`SN`), and executive planning (`ECN`).
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: The sequence represents a robust model of the cognitive steps involved in structured creative transformation, grounded in the known functions of the brain's memory, attentional, creative, and executive networks.

content.title: The Character-Driven Path
content.summary: Define Contradiction -> Challenge -> Generate
content.rationale: For narrative arts, this path generates plot from character, improved by starting with the character's 'core internal contradiction' to create more psychological depth.
activity_sequence: Instead of a simple desire/fear, start by defining the character's core internal contradiction or paradox (e.g., an honest man who must lie; a pacifist who must fight).
Develop the character's specific wants and fears as external manifestations of this core contradiction.
Create a premise that forces this internal contradiction to its breaking point.

activity_citation.citation_text: This pathway codifies a core principle of character-driven screenwriting and fiction, as taught in many creative writing programs.
activity_citation.rationale: The authority comes from the established pedagogical practices of creative writing. The principle of generating plot from a character's internal conflict is a foundational concept for creating compelling narratives.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Imagine a compelling character
Define their core desire and fear
Place them in a situation that challenges both
Generate story events from their likely actions

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: This is a plausible synthesis of known network functions. Imagining a character involves both creative simulation (`DMN`) and social cognition (`SCN`). Defining their motivations involves emotional (`Limbic`) and executive (`ECN`) processes. Generating the plot is a core executive function (`ECN`).
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: The sequence represents a robust model of the cognitive steps involved in character-driven narrative creation, integrating creative, social, emotional, and executive brain networks.

content.title: The Embodied Path
content.summary: Move -> Notice -> Capture Immediately
content.rationale: Uses physical movement to generate ideas, improved with a disciplined protocol for 'Immediate and Multi-modal Capture' to overcome the bottleneck of translating non-verbal insights.
activity_sequence: Physically act out the problem or theme ('bodystorming'), with capture tools readily available.
Pay close attention to emergent physical sensations and ideas.

The moment an insight is noticed, immediately stop and capture it using whatever modality is fastest and most natural (e.g., a voice memo, a quick photo of a pose, a rough sketch). Do not wait or analyze it first.
Later, review this raw 'capture log' to translate the insights.

activity_citation.citation_text: Oulasvirta, A., et al. (2003). Understanding contexts by being there: case studies in bodystorming. Personal and Ubiquitous Computing, 7(2), 125-134.
activity_citation.rationale: This is a key academic paper that formally defines and analyzes the "Bodystorming" methodology. The pathway's method of using physical enactment to generate insights is a direct application of this established design research technique.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Engage in a physical practice (e.g., dance, bodystorming)
Notice emergent feelings and ideas
Translate the embodied insight into another medium
Develop the translated concept

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: Varela, F. J., Thompson, E., & Rosch, E. (1991). The Embodied Mind. MIT Press.
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: This is a foundational text for Embodied Cognition. The pathway's sequence of learning through direct physical action (`Sensorimotor`) to generate an intuitive insight (`Insula`, `SN`) that is then formalized (`ECN`) is a direct application of the principles of embodied and enactive cognition.

content.title: The Foundational Path
content.summary: Diverge -> Compare -> Select a Portfolio
content.rationale: This is the universal, discipline-agnostic sequence for creative problem-solving. It ensures that a wide range of possibilities are generated before a premature decision is made, and concludes by selecting a strategic portfolio of options to carry forward, balancing risk and potential reward.
activity_sequence: Generate multiple, distinct options, hypotheses, or creative concepts using a method like Silent Brainstorming (N15).
Compare these options against the success criteria defined in Tool 2.
Converge by selecting a balanced 'portfolio' of the most promising options to prototype or test in the next tools (e.g., a safe bet, an ambitious bet).

activity_citation.citation_text: This pathway codifies the "Diverge/Converge" model, a core principle of Design Thinking.
activity_citation.rationale: The authority comes from the established, widespread practice of the Design Thinking methodology, which has been validated in countless innovation projects worldwide. The "Select a Portfolio" step is an addition from strategic management that improves the robustness of the final convergence.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Generate multiple, distinct options through divergent thinking, which involves a cooperative interplay between the DMN (for spontaneous idea generation) and the ECN (for combining ideas and strategic exploration).
Implement the 'defer judgment' rule by using the ECN to actively suppress its own default critical evaluation function, thereby enabling a broader, more divergent search.

Evaluate the generated options through a dual-process comparison: the vmPFC assesses each option's subjective value and alignment with implicit goals, while the ECN evaluates them against explicit, rule-based constraints.

Make a final, strategic selection. This is a higher-order ECN function that integrates the value signals for individual options to construct a 'portfolio' that satisfies a complex goal, such as balancing risk and reward.

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: Beaty, R. E., et al. (2016). Creative cognition and brain network dynamics. Trends in Cognitive Sciences, 20(2), 87-95.
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: This key paper provides the neuroscientific evidence for the interplay between the DMN and ECN during creative thought. The pathway's sequence of divergent generation (`DMN`), inhibition of judgment (`ECN`), and final evaluation (`vmPFC`, `ECN`) is a direct application of the cognitive model described in this authoritative review.

content.title: The User-Centered Path
content.summary: Empathize -> Frame 'How Might We' -> Brainstorm -> Select
content.rationale: Generates solutions grounded in user needs, improved with a mandatory 'bridging artifact' (HMW questions) to ensure the user's voice is not lost between empathy and ideation.
activity_sequence: Start with the key insights from your user empathy work.
Translate these insights into a set of specific, optimistic 'How Might We...' (HMW) questions. This is the crucial bridge from problem to solution.
Run a brainstorming session focused only on generating ideas that answer your top HMW questions.

activity_citation.citation_text: This pathway describes the "Ideate" phase of the Design Thinking process, as popularized by the Stanford d.school.
activity_citation.rationale: The authority comes from the established, widespread practice of the Design Thinking methodology. The use of "How Might We" questions to bridge from empathy to ideation is a core technique taught and validated by institutions like the d.school.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Empathize with user stories
Divergently brainstorm solutions
Assess value vs. effort
Select viable options for testing

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: Saxe, R., & Kanwisher, N. (2003). People thinking about thinking people: The role of the temporo-parietal junction in 'theory of mind'. NeuroImage, 19(4), 1835-1842.
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: The sequence begins with empathy (`SCN`). The subsequent brainstorming (`DMN`), assessment (`vmPFC`), and selection (`ECN`) are a classic model of creative problem-solving, grounded in the known functions of the brain's social, creative, and executive networks.

content.title: The Competitive Path
content.summary: Analyze -> Abstract the 'Job' -> Innovate
content.rationale: Generates ideas by analyzing competitors, improved by integrating Jobs-to-be-Done theory to shift focus from imitation to innovation.
activity_sequence: Analyze a competitor's product.
Abstract away from their features to identify the underlying 'Job-to-be-Done' (JTBD) that users are hiring the product to do.
Instead of just improving their features, brainstorm a novel way to get that same 'job' done for the user.

activity_citation.citation_text: Christensen, C. M., Cook, S., & Hall, T. (2007). Marketing Malpractice: The Cause and the Cure. In On Breakthrough Thinking. Harvard Business Press.
activity_citation.rationale: This is a key text that clearly defines the "Jobs-to-be-Done" (JTBD) theory. The pathway's method of abstracting from a competitor's features to the underlying "job" is a direct application of JTBD theory, which provides a powerful lens for differentiation.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Analyze competitor's product
Identify its weaknesses and opportunities
Imagine a "10x better" solution
Define a feature set to achieve it

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: This is a plausible synthesis of known network functions. The analysis is a focused task (`DAN`). Identifying weaknesses is a salience detection function (`SN`). Imagining a better solution is a creative, imaginative task (`DMN`), and defining the feature set is a core executive function (`ECN`).
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: The sequence represents a robust model of the cognitive steps involved in competitive innovation, integrating attention, salience detection, imagination, and executive control.

content.title: The Feature Factory Path
content.summary: Review -> Prune -> Extend -> Prioritize
content.rationale: A linear path for extending an existing product, improved with a mandatory, subtractive 'pruning' step to combat 'additive bias' and product bloat.
activity_sequence: Review the current product and its usage data.
First, hold a 'Pruning Session': Identify existing features that are low-value, high-maintenance, or create unnecessary complexity. Propose them for removal.
Only then, brainstorm a small, focused list of new features.
Prioritize a backlog that includes both the 'pruning' tasks and the new features.

activity_citation.citation_text: This pathway is a critique and improvement upon the common (though often criticized) "feature factory" mode of operation for mature product teams. The "Pruning" step is an addition from Lean principles to combat waste.
activity_citation.rationale: The authority comes from the critique of the "feature factory" model in modern product management literature. The pathway provides a structured method for moving from a purely additive mindset to a more strategic, subtractive one.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Review the existing product and backlog
Brainstorm logical next steps and feature extensions
Prioritize based on business goals
Add new user stories to the backlog

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: This is a plausible synthesis of known network functions. The sequence involves memory retrieval (`Hippo`), executive control (`ECN`), creative brainstorming (`DMN`), and value-based judgment (`vmPFC`).
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: The sequence represents a robust model of the cognitive steps involved in incremental product development, grounded in the known functions of the brain's memory, creative, and executive networks.

content.title: The Tech-Push Path
content.summary: Understand Tech -> Imagine Applications -> Validate Problem -> Conceptualize
content.rationale: Generates business ideas from new technology, improved with a mandatory 'problem validation' loop to prevent creating 'solutions in search of a problem'.
activity_sequence: Start with a deep understanding of a new technological capability.
Brainstorm a wide range of potential applications.
Pause and conduct rapid user research to validate which of these applications solves the most painful and valuable problem for a specific user group.
Select the single application that has the strongest problem-solution fit to develop.

activity_citation.citation_text: This pathway describes the principle of "technology push" innovation, a well-documented pattern in business history. The "Validate Problem" step is an addition from the Lean Startup methodology to improve the success rate of this approach.
activity_citation.rationale: The authority comes from the synthesis of two major innovation theories. It combines the reality of technology-driven innovation with the discipline of user-centered validation.

neurocognitive_sequence.step: Understand a new technology's capabilities
Imagine novel applications and business models
Identify the most promising market opportunity
Develop a business concept around it

neurocognitive_citation.citation_text: This is a plausible synthesis of known network functions. Understanding a technology is an analytical task (`DAN`, `ECN`). Imagining applications is a creative task (`DMN`). Identifying the best opportunity involves salience detection (`SN`) and value judgment (`vmPFC`), and developing the concept is a core executive function (`ECN`).
neurocognitive_citation.rationale: The sequence represents a robust model of the cognitive steps involved in technology-push innovation, integrating analytical, creative, and executive brain networks.

content.title: The Business Model Path
content.summary: Map -> Apply Patterns -> Test
content.rationale: Innovates on the business model, improved by introducing a 'pattern library' to provide concrete starting points and overcome the 'blank canvas' problem.
activity_sequence: Use the Business Model Canvas to map out the current business model.

Instead of an unstructured brainstorm, systematically apply a library of proven business model patterns (e.g., 'Freemium,' 'Subscription,' 'Two-Sided Market') to your canvas to generate innovative variations.
